text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- The new ministers of Prime Minister Tiit Vaehi were sworn in at a parliament session. The appointment of Andra Veidemann as minister for European reforms has not yet been approved by the president.
- Russia did not agree to sign a border deal with Estonia at the OSCE meeting in Lisbon and experts do not consider a signing likely.
- The government signed a resolution removing the article that bans protective tariffs on imported farm produce.
- The electoral committee called for fines on five parties which failed to submit their reports on spending on the local election campaign.
- New Social Minister Tiiu Aro has called for an increae in minimum wages.
- The plan for the production of missile components at the Dvigatel plant is developing as the vice-president of Matra brought along drawings of the components to be made in Tallinn.
- The cost of water will go up with the introduction of new water treatment plants in several towns.
- Parliament introduced a new voting system which cost 2.9 million kroons.
- The government submitted a draft law on the introduction of a sentence of life imprisonment as a step towards the abolition of the death penalty.
- Around 1,000 Estonian citizens living on the Russian side of the bprder will be repatriated to Estonia if the border deal is signed.
- Several fuel suppliers cut their prices yesterday. The daily presumes that the reason is the large number of fuel outlets.
- Increased beer duty has not resulted in a rise of the price of local beer, which is expected to take place in a ew weeks.
